Dr. David Discusses Nuclear Missiles in Europe
by Gregg Weinstock
The College Republicans
sponsored a talk by Dr. Steven
David on intermediate nuclear
forces in Europe on October 6.
About fifty people came to the
Political Science seminar room
for the lecture.
David first defined strategic
and theater nuclear weapons.
Strategic weapons are "homeland to homeland" missiles
such as the ICBM. Theater
weapons are those used at
shorter distances."While thereis a rough parity between the
United States and the Soviet
Union in regard to strategic
weapons, the USSR is superior
in theater weapons in Europe,"

said David.
The Pershing 2 and Cruise
missiles, scheduled for deployment at the end of 1983 if no
arms control pact is reached in
Geneva, are intermediate range
or theater weapons.
The Soviets are opposed to
the Pershing 2 and Cruise deployment because they would
be American missiles under
American control in Europe
capable of reaching the USSR
in 5 to 6 minutes.
Presently, there are no
NATO missiles in Europe; the
Soviets have 250 SS-20 missiles
and 250 other types of missiles
in Eastern Europe, according to
David. The basic reason for the
deployment of American mis-

siles is to defend Western
Europe. The U.S. could probably not repel a Soviet invasion
by conventional means.
This situation presents problems, said David. The Soviets
would be more inclined to use
their missiles first if it appeared
that America would do so to
defend Western Europe.
Within Western European
nations, many people are opposed to U.S. missiles on their
territory. They want to put
nuclear weapons out of their
mind. With good reason, they
do not want Europe to be a
nuclear battleground.
Another problem with the
missiles is that they are being
used as bargaining chips, said

David. It is a bad precedent to
deploy because it is much more
difficult to dismantle arms once
they are in place than it is to
simply not build or deploy
them.
What are the options? President Reagan proposed the zero
option in which the Soviets
would destroy all their missiles
in Europe and the U.S. would
not deploy the Pershing 2 and
Cruise missiles. The Soviets rejected this proposal because
they stated that the U.S. was
making no concession in exchange for the reduction.
In his recent UN address,

Keep Your Doors Locked
It may seem bizarre, but it does happen.
People do die while they're sleeping, and it's
not always related to natural causes.
Sometimes people are murdered in bed.
Supposedly, there's someone in this
neighborhood who walks around at night
checking to see if people leave their doors
open. And if they do, he walks inside and
sees if anyone's there. He checks every room,
even the kitchen in case he's hungry, until
he gets to the bedrooms.
He slowly walks toward the bed or beds,
depending upon which room he decides to
visit first, and if anyone happens to be sleeping, he won't be sleeping much longer. He'll
be dead or pretty damn close to it. It doesn't
even matter how he kills him. He could use
a gun or a sledgehammer or a butcher's knife
or a pillow or perhaps a chainsaw. Whichever way he chooses, people will still die.
And he'll kill as many people as he wants.
It's almost like it can't happen, like it's
one of those things that could never happen
to you, one of those incidents that just seems
so strange, you can't believe it could ever
happen to anyone.
But it does happen, and people do get
killed.
It happened a few years ago at an obscure
college. There were two female roommates,
and one of them went on a date one night
while the other one stayed home. The one
who went on the date came back early be-

cause she wasn't feeling well.
The following morning, only one of the
roommates woke up. The other one was
dead, with a knife lodged in her back. Blood
was splattered all over the room. Clothes
were in and out of drawers. Stockings were
hanging from the lamps. The telephone cord
was yanked out of the wall. And above one
of the dressers was a mirror and on the mirror was a message written in lipstick:
"It's a good thing you didn't turn on the
light last night because if you had, you
wouldn't be reading this now."
No one ever found out how the murderer
got into the room. The door was probably
left unlocked. Or perhaps the murderer was
in the room before his victim went to sleep.
He might have also hid under the bed or inside a closet.
Waiting for someone to leave a door open
is another way to enter a dormitory or apartment room. The murderer can then hide behind the door. And when the student returns
from talking to some friends living down the
hall, he won't be living the comfortable life
of a college co-ed much longer. He'll be dead
or just seriously injured with one of his arms
dangling from its socket.
Three years ago, a freshman left her dormitory door open. And when she returned,
she looked inside her room and someone,
not her roommate, was standing behind the
door. She decided not to go inside.

A Safer Hopkins, Perhaps?
To the Editor:
An attack on a woman and
several near traffic accidents
demonstrate that safety is a
concern in the Merryman HallOlin Hall area.
The woman was attacked last
night before 10 p.m. on the
walk next to Merryman Hall on
the north side. We understand
that fortunately she escaped
with only a few injuries. Traffic near-misses oceur at the

Martin Drive near plin Hall.
There are two i problems:
lighting is uneven at night, and
vision is obscured by day and
night by the high stone walls of
the bridge. We suggest solutions for these problems.
Lighting is dim at the eastern
part of the walk, and at the
western end near the entrance
to Olin Hall. At the San Martin Drive crossing, the street
lights give little light. Their
lenses seem discolored and
partly opaque.
The traffic problem is that
people crossing San Martin in
the designated pedestrian walk
cannot see or hear small cars
coming south on the bridge.
Drivers of small cars cannot see
the pedestrians until the last
moment. There are three reasons—the road has a sharp
curve, the bridge walls are high,
and the pavement is so smooth
that cars can travel quietly.
We suggest the following
steps be taken:
1. The lighting could be improved on the walk next to
Merryman Hall, and at its end
near Olin Hall.
2. The street lights could be
repaired, with new downwardprojecting lenses.
3. Two rumble strips or two
sections of grooved pavement
could be put on the bridge
pavement on the southbound
side, to give an audible warning
to pedestrians that a vehicle is
approaching. That audible warning could also be useful to
drivers of cars pulling out of the
passenger drop-off point in
front of Olin Hall, the site of
several near-misses recently.
The sound should not be a
bother to people in buildings
nearby because of screening by
the bridge walls.

4. A flashing sign warning of
pedestrian crossing and vehicle
loading might be placed north
of the crossing. A driver hardly notices the present crossing
sign north of the bridge because
his concentration is diverted by
the sudden appearance of the
sharp turn and the high walls of
the bridge. A flashing sign has
already been installed north of
the Space Telescope building.
We suggest that the university's neighbors be considered if
the lighting is improved: the
lights should be installed so as
not to shine across the park to
annoy our neighbors on Gilman
Terrace. This is especially important in winter, when leaf fall
removes the screen for those
lights. This can be done by using downward-projecting lenses
for street lights, and by aiming
any flashing traffic signs away
from Gilman Terrace.
Attitudes toward safety have
improved markedly at the
Homewood campus in the past
few years. We urge that the
area near Merryman and Olin
Halls receive more attention.

Beginning next semester,
Hopkins students will no longer
receive credits for drama
courses taken at Peabody and

etc.

affiliated with Peabody and the
Maryland Institute of Art,
former Assistant Dean for
Undergraduate and Graduate
Studies Michael Hooker decided that credit would be given
for courses taken at these
schools.
The decision did not reflect
a change in policy, however.
"The Academic Council never
approved that we give credit for
these courses," Roseman said.
Roseman recommended that,
even though credits will not be
given, mention should be made
of the courses taken on the
students' transcripts.
"We would certainly like to
see kids get recognition for having taken the courses because it
shows what kind of people they
are," said Roseman.
Roseman said she has been
warning students about the new
decision. She said that Hopkins
students can still take courses in
piano, drama, voice, and so on
at reduced rates at the two
institutes.

The giraffe house of the Baltimore Zoo has been decimated by
ganglioneuritis. Zookeepers are monitoring the health of the two giraffes still alive.

The Baltimore Zoo's Giraffe
House is now home to only two
giraffes. Seven giraffes have
died in the past two years. Five
of the zoo's giraffes have died
in the last two months.
In August of this year, Scarface, Termite, and Prudence
died of a "wasting syndrome."
In September, Colleen, a fiveBaltimore-born
year-old
giraffe, one of the zoo's most
popular animals, also died of
the mysterious syndrome. In
late September, Patience, a
healthy giraffe, died of stress
after the complicated stillborn
birth of a calf, in circumstances
apparently unrelated to the
deadly syndrome.
The Giraffe House is closed
to the public while zookeepers
anxiously monitor the health of
Raymond and Angel, the only
giraffes left. As of writing they
are said to be fit and are not exhibiting any characteristics of
the "wasting syndrome."
The syndrome, known as
ganglioneuritis,is a disease that
attacks the nerve endings in the
intestines and causes a loss of
appetite and anemia. Researchers from Johns Hopkins, the
National Zoo, the University of
Maryland, the National Institutes of Health and the
University of Guelph in Ontario are seeking clues to the
cause of the disease. Apparently other zoos have lost groups
of giraffes to the syndrome, but
none has lost as many as quickly as the Baltimore Zoo has.
The Baltimore Zoo has now
ended plans to specialize in
breeding its giraffes, all of
whom were Angolans(a deserttype giraffe which is found in
the southern portions of Africa)
of the reticulated species. Until more is discovered about the
disease, zoo officials do not
plan to replace the giraffes or
to reopen the Giraffe House to
the public.

EAM Strives To Educate Public About Epilepsy
by Jay Schneider
In the United States, there
are more than two million epileptics, or nearly one percent of
the country's population. Each
Year 100,000 new cases are reported, mostly among children.
About 40,000 Maryland residents are epileptics. The Epilepsy Association of Maryland
(EAM)is located at 3121 Saint
Paul Street. Its purpose is to
address the major problems
that epileptics have. It is affiliated with the Epilepsy Foundation of America, which has
a national office located in
Washington, D.C. EAM provides a variety of services for its
clients.
The Training and Placement
Service assists epileptics in finding and keeping long-term emPloyment. Epilepsy, as a handi-

cap, has the highest unemployment; many employers are reluctant to hire epileptics. A
related problem to that of finding employment is the difficulty of obtaining insurance. Recently, it has become easier for
epileptics to obtain coverage,
but they are subject to exclusions for any claims related to
epilepsy.
EAM runs a program in the
Baltimore City School System
whose purpose is to identify
those students, fourteen or
older, who have epilepsy. Once
they are identified, the students
can obtain proper medical and
social care.
A variety of counseling services are provided by EAM.
There is a self-help group that
meets monthly. It is similar in
its set-up to Alcoholics Anonymous; both rely upon the ideas

of peer counseling and the
training of people to be peer
leaders.
Individual counseling of epileptics is also available. Often,
clients come through referrals
from doctors. Some clients who
have already gone_ to government social service agencies
find that EAM is their last
resort, after the government
agency referred them to EAM.
Once the client arrives, he sees
a counselor, and the epileptic's
social, psychological, and medical needs are assessed. No
medical diagnoses are made on
the premises; instead the client
is referred to a doctor or a
neurologist.
EAM provides professional
training for teachers, nurses,
social workers, and emergency
medical teams. The staff also
helps epileptics locate social,

medical, and educational assistance or assistance in other
areas that may not be available
at the Baltimore City location.
One of the major ongoing
purposes of EAM is to educate
the general public about epilepsy and to dispel the various
myths surrounding it. Epilpesy
was once thought to be caused
by demonic possession. Many
people connected epilepsy with
insanity. Only three years ago,
at a county fair in Hagerstown
where EAM had a booth, people congregated in front of the
booth, praying for the demons
to leave the bodies of the
epileptics.
In reality, epilepsy is a
manifestation of excessive and
synchronous electrical discharges of a large number of cerebral neurons. Epilepsy itself is
not a disease; rather, it is the

manifestation of one or more il—
lnesses. Epilepsy can be caused
by head trauma at birth, meningitis, brain tumors, brain injuries, brain abscesses, and
related I occur,rences.The outward signs of epilepsy may not
become obvious until years
after the injury was sustained,
or after the illness has run its

Wide Boy Awake
WIDE BOY AWAKE
At first glance I was prepared
to hate this record. Just another
MTV band, I thought—shmaltzy designer costumes, toughguy makeup—all style and no
substance. But as soon as I
heard the first few minutes of
the album, I realized that Wide
Boy Awake is a "Nu-Musik"
band with a difference. Unlike
Culture Club, Duran Duran,
and the rest of the Glitz-Blitz
crowd, this highly fashionable
foursome has muscial talent as
well as good looks.
Wide Boy Awake was founded by former Ant Kevin Mooney. Adam's influence, both
musical and visual, is readily
apparent. The rhythms and
music, drawing from a wide
range of sources including
Caribbean, African, Cajun,
and even Country music, are
often reminiscent of the better
music from the Ant's early albums. Yet there is also a freshness and originality to Wide
Boy Awake's music that is generally lacking among the better
known Adam Ant clone bands.
This self-titled debut record,
a five song e.p., begins with the
Wide Boy Awake MTV and
club hit, Chicken Outlaw.
Opening with a pounding syn-

thesiser and drum beat, this irresistably danceable song
breaks out into a techno-Creole
foot-stomper. Another Cajunesque romp, Bona Venture, is
without a doubt the best dance
song of the year. Sounding a
little like the Clash's Let's Go
Crazy with added fiddle, this
tune is enough to make even the
most hardcore D-leveler jump
up from his seat and make like
Fred Astaire.
While none of the other
songs on this record are quite so
rousing, they are at least much
better examples of synth-funk
than most other "nu-musik"
bands are providing. Slang
Teacher, for example, another
club hit, packs just enough
punch to keep it from droning.
Hopefully, future releases from
W.B.A. will lean more heavily
on the Caribbean and Cajun influences and shy away from the
more bland techno-pop shlock.
What about the lyrics? Who
knows? And who cares? This
music is for dancing, not thinking. For all I know, the words
may be just as clever as the
music. But I was having too
much fun enjoying dancing to
this record to sit down and concentrate on what it was saying.
In short, Wide Boy Awake
may just be the best dance band
to come out of the Video Revolution. Their debut album certainly is the most fun.

It may seem bizarre, but it does happen.
People do die while they're sleeping, and it's
not always related to natural causes.
Sometimes people are murdered in bed.
Supposedly, there's someone in this
neighborhood who walks around at night
checking to see if people leave their doors
open. And if they do, he walks inside and
sees if anyone's there. He checks every room,
even the kitchen in case he's hungry, until
he gets to the bedrooms.
He slowly walks toward the bed or beds,
depending upon which room he decides to
visit first, and if anyone happens to be sleeping, he won't be sleeping much longer. He'll
be dead or pretty damn close to it. It doesn't
even matter how he kills him. He could use
a gun or a sledgehammer or a butcher's knife
or a pillow or perhaps a chainsaw. Whichever way he chooses, people will still die.
And he'll kill as many people as he wants.
It's almost like it can't happen, like it's
one of those things that could never happen
to you, one of those incidents that just seems
so strange, you can't believe it could ever
happen to anyone.
But it does happen, and people do get
killed.
It happened a few years ago at an obscure
college. There were two female roommates,
and one of them went on a date one night
while the other one stayed home. The one
who went on the date came back early be-

cause she wasn't feeling well.
The following morning, only one of the
roommates woke up. The other one was
dead, with a knife lodged in her back. Blood
was splattered all over the room. Clothes
were in and out of drawers. Stockings were
hanging from the lamps. The telephone cord
was yanked out of the wall. And above one
of the dressers was a mirror and on the mirror was a message written in lipstick:
"It's a good thing you didn't turn on the
light last night because if you had, you
wouldn't be reading this now."
No one ever found out how the murderer
got into the room. The door was probably
left unlocked. Or perhaps the murderer was
in the room before his victim went to sleep.
He might have also hid under the bed or inside a closet.
Waiting for someone to leave a door open
is another way to enter a dormitory or apartment room. The murderer can then hide behind the door. And when the student returns
from talking to some friends living down the
hall, he won't be living the comfortable life
of a college co-ed much longer. He'll be dead
or just seriously injured with one of his arms
dangling from its socket.
Three years ago, a freshman left her dormitory door open. And when she returned,
she looked inside her room and someone,
not her roommate, was standing behind the
door. She decided not to go inside.

The giraffe house of the Baltimore Zoo has been decimated by
ganglioneuritis. Zookeepers are monitoring the health of the two giraffes still alive.

The Baltimore Zoo's Giraffe
House is now home to only two
giraffes. Seven giraffes have
died in the past two years. Five
of the zoo's giraffes have died
in the last two months.
In August of this year, Scarface, Termite, and Prudence
died of a "wasting syndrome."
In September, Colleen, a fiveBaltimore-born
year-old
giraffe, one of the zoo's most
popular animals, also died of
the mysterious syndrome. In
late September, Patience, a
healthy giraffe, died of stress
after the complicated stillborn
birth of a calf, in circumstances
apparently unrelated to the
deadly syndrome.
The Giraffe House is closed
to the public while zookeepers
anxiously monitor the health of
Raymond and Angel, the only
giraffes left. As of writing they
are said to be fit and are not exhibiting any characteristics of
the "wasting syndrome."
The syndrome, known as
ganglioneuritis,is a disease that
attacks the nerve endings in the
intestines and causes a loss of
appetite and anemia. Researchers from Johns Hopkins, the
National Zoo, the University of
Maryland, the National Institutes of Health and the
University of Guelph in Ontario are seeking clues to the
cause of the disease. Apparently other zoos have lost groups
of giraffes to the syndrome, but
none has lost as many as quickly as the Baltimore Zoo has.
The Baltimore Zoo has now
ended plans to specialize in
breeding its giraffes, all of
whom were Angolans(a deserttype giraffe which is found in
the southern portions of Africa)
of the reticulated species. Until more is discovered about the
disease, zoo officials do not
plan to replace the giraffes or
to reopen the Giraffe House to
the public.

EAM Strives To Educate Public About Epilepsy
by Jay Schneider
In the United States, there
are more than two million epileptics, or nearly one percent of
the country's population. Each
Year 100,000 new cases are reported, mostly among children.
About 40,000 Maryland residents are epileptics. The Epilepsy Association of Maryland
(EAM)is located at 3121 Saint
Paul Street. Its purpose is to
address the major problems
that epileptics have. It is affiliated with the Epilepsy Foundation of America, which has
a national office located in
Washington, D.C. EAM provides a variety of services for its
clients.
The Training and Placement
Service assists epileptics in finding and keeping long-term emPloyment. Epilepsy, as a handi-

cap, has the highest unemployment; many employers are reluctant to hire epileptics. A
related problem to that of finding employment is the difficulty of obtaining insurance. Recently, it has become easier for
epileptics to obtain coverage,
but they are subject to exclusions for any claims related to
epilepsy.
EAM runs a program in the
Baltimore City School System
whose purpose is to identify
those students, fourteen or
older, who have epilepsy. Once
they are identified, the students
can obtain proper medical and
social care.
A variety of counseling services are provided by EAM.
There is a self-help group that
meets monthly. It is similar in
its set-up to Alcoholics Anonymous; both rely upon the ideas

of peer counseling and the
training of people to be peer
leaders.
Individual counseling of epileptics is also available. Often,
clients come through referrals
from doctors. Some clients who
have already gone_ to government social service agencies
find that EAM is their last
resort, after the government
agency referred them to EAM.
Once the client arrives, he sees
a counselor, and the epileptic's
social, psychological, and medical needs are assessed. No
medical diagnoses are made on
the premises; instead the client
is referred to a doctor or a
neurologist.
EAM provides professional
training for teachers, nurses,
social workers, and emergency
medical teams. The staff also
helps epileptics locate social,

medical, and educational assistance or assistance in other
areas that may not be available
at the Baltimore City location.
One of the major ongoing
purposes of EAM is to educate
the general public about epilepsy and to dispel the various
myths surrounding it. Epilpesy
was once thought to be caused
by demonic possession. Many
people connected epilepsy with
insanity. Only three years ago,
at a county fair in Hagerstown
where EAM had a booth, people congregated in front of the
booth, praying for the demons
to leave the bodies of the
epileptics.
In reality, epilepsy is a
manifestation of excessive and
synchronous electrical discharges of a large number of cerebral neurons. Epilepsy itself is
not a disease; rather, it is the

manifestation of one or more il—
lnesses. Epilepsy can be caused
by head trauma at birth, meningitis, brain tumors, brain injuries, brain abscesses, and
related I occur,rences.The outward signs of epilepsy may not
become obvious until years
after the injury was sustained,
or after the illness has run its
course. Any number of things
could trigger a seizure, such as
fatigue, extreme cold, consumption of alcohol, or lack of
medication. Medication can
totally control the seizures of
approximately fifty percent of
epileptics. Another thirty percent have their seizures partially controlled, while the Epilepsy Foundation of America estimates twenty percent of all
epileptics are not taking medication, and their seizures are
not controlled.

Wide Boy Awake
WIDE BOY AWAKE
At first glance I was prepared
to hate this record. Just another
MTV band, I thought—shmaltzy designer costumes, toughguy makeup—all style and no
substance. But as soon as I
heard the first few minutes of
the album, I realized that Wide
Boy Awake is a "Nu-Musik"
band with a difference. Unlike
Culture Club, Duran Duran,
and the rest of the Glitz-Blitz
crowd, this highly fashionable
foursome has muscial talent as
well as good looks.
Wide Boy Awake was founded by former Ant Kevin Mooney. Adam's influence, both
musical and visual, is readily
apparent. The rhythms and
music, drawing from a wide
range of sources including
Caribbean, African, Cajun,
and even Country music, are
often reminiscent of the better
music from the Ant's early albums. Yet there is also a freshness and originality to Wide
Boy Awake's music that is generally lacking among the better
known Adam Ant clone bands.
This self-titled debut record,
a five song e.p., begins with the
Wide Boy Awake MTV and
club hit, Chicken Outlaw.
Opening with a pounding syn-

thesiser and drum beat, this irresistably danceable song
breaks out into a techno-Creole
foot-stomper. Another Cajunesque romp, Bona Venture, is
without a doubt the best dance
song of the year. Sounding a
little like the Clash's Let's Go
Crazy with added fiddle, this
tune is enough to make even the
most hardcore D-leveler jump
up from his seat and make like
Fred Astaire.
While none of the other
songs on this record are quite so
rousing, they are at least much
better examples of synth-funk
than most other "nu-musik"
bands are providing. Slang
Teacher, for example, another
club hit, packs just enough
punch to keep it from droning.
Hopefully, future releases from
W.B.A. will lean more heavily
on the Caribbean and Cajun influences and shy away from the
more bland techno-pop shlock.
What about the lyrics? Who
knows? And who cares? This
music is for dancing, not thinking. For all I know, the words
may be just as clever as the
music. But I was having too
much fun enjoying dancing to
this record to sit down and concentrate on what it was saying.
In short, Wide Boy Awake
may just be the best dance band
to come out of the Video Revolution. Their debut album certainly is the most fun.

Reid Leads Hopkins In Water Polo Tourney
by Bruce Cairns
Up at the pool this weekend,
the Johns Hopkins Waterpolo
Team hosted the first of two
MAC Division II tournaments.
The team played four games,
going 2-2 for the weekend.
Hopkins opened the tournament on Friday with a strong
19-8 victory over St. Francis.
Standouts in the game were
sophomore Tom Reid with 7
goals, classmate Tito Hernandez with four goals, and excellent defensive efforts by the
pair of goalies, frosh Ted Smith
and sophomore Wink Dyer.
Saturday morning, the Blue
Jays suffered a heartbreaking
loss to Indiana of Pennsylvania, losing by a score of 11-10.
Saturday night Hopkins was
back and ready for a tough
Penn State team. Hopkins was
ahead by only one goal at
halftime, but by the end of the
game, the Jays had abused the
Penn State goalie for five goals,
smothering the Nittany Lions
offense for a final score of
18-13.
The final game for the Jays
was held Sunday morning at
9:00 a.m. against Cornell.
"Cornell was the toughest
game for us," said captain
Mark Oliver. "We jumped out
to an early lead (3-0 in the first
quarter)and held on for as long
as we could, but in the end we
just gave out. I think we could
have won the game, but we just
didn't want it bad enough."
Hopkins was ahead until the
fourth quarter when Cornell
took over and scored six goals
for a 13-7 victory. When asked
if he thought the team could get

itself together to repeat as
MAC champions this year, Oliver said, "Definitely. That last
game (against Cornell) wasn't
played very well. We gave
everything we had too early and
just got tired. But we have the
talent and the skill to win
MAC's again."
Hopkins will play the second
half of the tournament at Cornell in two weeks. Seven out of
the 10 teams in the tournament
will advance to the MAC cham-

pionships.

Jays must win at least two more
games to qualify.
